PARENTS OF IN-SCHOOL AND VIRTUAL STUDENTS: As the new school year kicks off, we’d like to share those precious pictures of your students!

Every year, the school district takes dozens of pictures at all S-G schools on opening day. This year, we’d like to see what you see in the morning – whether it's on your front porch, at your child's at-home work station or heading to the school.

Please snap some back-to-school pictures and send them to us. You can send your pictures to Robert Hanlon at rhanlon@sgcsd.net. With kindergartners starting on Sept. 21, we will accept pictures until Wednesday, Sept. 23. PLEASE BE SURE TO LET US KNOW YOUR STUDENT'S GRADE AND SCHOOL.

We will compile all of our community’s photos into a photo album on Facebook and feature some of them on the school district’s website. We look forward to welcoming your children back to school and we wish everyone a wonderful start to the year!

Buffalo Chicken Wrap - Crispy buffalo chicken, romaine, tomato, red onion, blue cheese dressing, cheddar jalapeño wrap. Served with fries.

Pear & Walnut Salad - Spring mix, diced pears, walnuts, dried cranberries, blue cheese crumbles, white balsamic vinaigrette.

Available starting today (7/7) and running until 7/19. Meals must be ordered during this time frame. No exceptions. No Substitutions. Meals are takeout only.

We are so proud of you all for persevering during these unprecedented times! We hope you enjoy!

Mike, Steph, & Mohawk Staff

Effective Tuesday, March 17, 2020, breakfast and lunch will be available to all students from 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. weekdays.

The pick-up location for these meals will be the High School, in the side parking lot, which will be marked as a designated area for this purpose.

This process will be on a “grab & go” basis. Offerings will include bagels, cereal, muffins, and cheese for breakfast and sandwiches, fruits, vegetables, milk, and pizza for lunch.

Cars will pull into a line in the High School parking lot and district staff will deliver the meals directly to the cars. At this time, we will be providing meals on a daily basis and will update our families if and when this changes.

If you are in need of food for your children but cannot come to the high school, we will have food delivered to you. Simply contact the District Office at 518-347-3600, ext. 71100.

Please let me know if you have any questions or require further information.

If you don’t succeed at first, try, try again!

ALBANY -- For senior Andrew Roche, good things come when you wait.

Roche, who attends Capital Region BOCES from the Scotia-Glenville Central School District, is in the auto services program, but that is not where he got his start at BOCES.

“Last year, I was in welding and it wasn’t for me, but I helped my father change the oil on his car and something just clicked. I felt called to do it,” Roche said. “I learned that automotive repair is something I like to do.”

AS a result, he switched programs to auto services this year and is enjoying his learning and education.

“It’s fun. I enjoy what I am doing,” he said.

Roche is one of more than 100 students in the various automotive repair programs at Capital Region BOCES. He is learning everything from vehicle maintaince to detailing in the auto services program, one of half-dozen automotive repair programs offered by BOCES.

PHOTO RELEASE - Smiling while ‘stewing’ at Capital Region BOCES

ALBANY -- Messiah Blackman and Melody Francis are all smiles while preparing beef stew in the Capital Region BOCES cosmetology lab in Albany. Blackman of Scotia-Glenville and Francis of Niskayuna are juniors in the two-year program which prepares students for careers in the kitchen.

Located at both the Albany and Schoharie campuses, the Capital Region BOCES culinary program serves nearly 100 students, preparing them to enter the workforce or pursue additional training in college. Graduates work in restaurants and resorts around the region and beyond, own their establishment and even prepare food for professional sporting events.

“I want to be a chef because my uncle was one and I want to follow in his footsteps,” Blackman said.
